name: Occupational Therapy (OT)
summary: A licensed, evidence-based rehabilitation profession that helps people participate in meaningful daily activities (occupations) through skill-building, adaptation, and environmental modification.
description: Occupational Therapy enables people across the lifespan to do what matters to them—self-care, work/school, play, and community participation. OTs use activity analysis, graded practice, assistive technology, cognitive and motor rehabilitation, and environmental modifications to optimize function after injury, illness, disability, or mental health challenges. Practice spans hospitals, rehab, schools, primary care, and community settings. OT is strongly evidence-based for improving functional independence and quality of life in numerous conditions (e.g., stroke, hand injury, developmental and mental health conditions).

practice_styles: Rehabilitation and biomechanical (strength, ROM, edema management)
Cognitive rehabilitation and executive function training
Sensory integration and sensory processing approaches (pediatrics)
delivery_methods: Group interventions (e.g., energy conservation, social skills)
metadata.session_duration: 30–60 minutes typical; acute care may be 15–30 minutes
treatment_duration: Short blocks (4–12 sessions) for focused goals
Longer courses for complex neurological or developmental needs
metadata.training_required: Licensed Occupational Therapist (OTR/L) or Occupational Therapy Assistant (COTA) under supervision; graduate degree and national/state licensure.
metadata.regulatory_status: Licensed allied health profession with standardized scope and ethics; title protection in most jurisdictions.

primary_indications: Cognitive and executive dysfunction affecting daily life
conditions_treated: Stroke and TBI (upper-limb function, ADLs, cognition)
Arthritis and chronic pain (joint protection, energy conservation)
Autism spectrum and developmental coordination disorder
off_label_uses: Primary prevention via workplace ergonomics and injury reduction
Lifestyle redesign for chronic disease self-management
contraindications: Absolute: None inherent to OT; follows medical precautions (e.g., non–weight-bearing limbs, sternal precautions).
Relative: Acute medical instability; uncontrolled pain/fatigue requiring medical management before activity.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Low risk. Main concerns are overexertion, falls during mobility practice, or skin issues with orthoses—mitigated by screening, monitoring vitals, and proper fitting.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong overall for functional outcomes in stroke, hand therapy, and geriatric rehab; moderate for cognitive rehab and pediatric goals; supportive for mental health role participation.

items: Difficulty with self-care, home, school, or work tasks
Motor and cognitive deficits after injury/illness
Community mobility and driver rehab needs
Need for home/work accessibility and assistive tech

sections.text: OT applies activity analysis and graded, meaningful tasks to drive neuroplasticity, motor learning, and habit formation. Interventions pair task-specific practice with environmental adaptations, assistive tech, and compensatory strategies. Psychosocial approaches bolster self-efficacy, role identity, and participation, while biomechanical methods address strength, ROM, and edema to improve task performance.

sections.preparation: Functional assessment (ADL/IADL measures), cognitive and motor screening, environmental and role analysis; establish client-centered goals.
procedure: Task-specific training for priority occupations (e.g., dressing, meal prep, returning to work/school).
Remediation (motor/cognitive exercises) and compensation (checklists, memory aids, adaptive tools).
Orthoses/splints or assistive devices; home/work modifications and caregiver education.
Outcome tracking with validated measures; iterate plan.
sections.frequency: 1–3 sessions/week typical; intensity varies by setting and goals.
sections.total_treatment_time: 4–12+ weeks depending on condition severity and goals.

items: Neurological OT (CIMT, task-oriented training, UE rehab)
Mental health OT (routine building, social skills, coping)

immediate: Improved task strategies, better energy conservation, increased confidence
short_term: Higher independence in ADLs/IADLs, improved motor control and cognition for daily tasks
long_term: Sustained community participation, reduced caregiver burden, improved quality of life

rare: Falls or overexertion (screened and mitigated by therapist)

relative: Medical precautions (e.g., weight-bearing limits, sternal/hip precautions)
Orthostatic intolerance—monitor vitals and modify tasks
special_considerations: Use fall-prevention strategies and safe transfer training.
Fit and monitor orthoses; inspect skin regularly.
Tailor cognitive load and sensory input to tolerance.

ideal_candidates: People whose health condition limits daily roles or independence
Caregivers needing training and environmental support
Children with developmental or school participation challenges
Adults returning to work/school after illness or injury
screening_required: Validated baseline measures (e.g., FIM/AMPAC, DASH/QuickDASH, MoCA)

lifestyle_recommendations: Home exercise and practice of targeted tasks
Use of calendars, reminders, and checklists

sections.typical_session_cost: $100–$250 per session (private pay; varies by region)
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered when medically necessary; benefits vary by plan and setting (hospital, outpatient, school-based)

items: Set functional, measurable goals tied to client priorities.
Combine remediation with compensatory and environmental strategies.
Document outcomes using validated measures to track progress and justify care.
Educate caregivers to generalize gains across contexts.
